}} 'Eric Arthur Blair' (25 June 1903 â 21 January 1950), known by his
pen name 'George Orwell', was an English novelist, and journalist. His work is
marked by clarity, awareness of social injustice, opposition to totalitarianism,
and commitment to democratic socialism. "Why I Write" in The Collected
Essays, Journalism and Letters of George Orwell Volume 1 â An Age Like This
1945â1950 p.23 (Penguin)

Considered perhaps the 20th century's best chronicler of English
culture, Orwell wrote literary criticism, poetry, fiction and
polemical journalism. He is best known for the dystopian novel [[Nineteen Eighty-
Four]] (1949) and the allegorical novella [[Animal Farm]] (1945), which together
(as of 2009) have sold more copies than any two books by any other 20th-century
author. His book [[Homage to Catalonia]] (1938), an account of his
experiences in the Spanish Civil War, is widely acclaimed, as are his numerous
essays on politics, literature, language, and culture. In 2008, [[The Times]]
ranked him second on a list of "The 50 greatest British writers since
1945". {{cite news|url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and-
_entertainment/books/article3127837.ece |title=The 50 greatest British writers
since 1945|date=5 January 2008|work=The Times |accessdate=31 January
2012}}

Orwell's work continues to influence popular and political culture, and the term
[[Orwellian]] â descriptive of totalitarian or authoritarian social practices â
has entered the language together with several of his neologisms, including
[[Cold War]], [[Big Brother (Nineteen Eighty-Four)|Big Brother]], [[thought
police]], [[Room 101]], [[doublethink]], and [[thoughtcrime]]. [http://www.guardian.co.uk/books/2009/may/10/1984-george-
orwell Robert McCrum, The Observer, 10 May 2009]
categories: British people of the Spanish Civil War
People educated at Wellington College, Berkshire
